commander.name: Major-General Harold Freeman-Attwood
commander.previous_service: Replaced Major-General Miles Dempsey in October 1941. Led division through training in UK 1941-1942 and deployment to North Africa December 1942.
commander.note: Freeman-Attwood commanded through Tunisia Campaign. Replaced by Major-General John Hawkesworth on 25 August 1943 before Salerno landings.

command.headquarters_location: Tunisia - Initially near Sedjenane (January), later Beja sector (February-March), final offensive operations towards Tunis (April-May)

tanks.note: Infantry division - no organic tanks. Supported by Churchill tanks from North Irish Horse and other armored regiments during operations.

Ordnance QF 25-pounder.note: Three field regiments (72 guns) plus divisional artillery (24 guns). Provided substantial fire support at Hunt's Gap and other operations.

Ordnance QF 17-pounder (76mm).note: Limited allocation of new 17-pdr guns for anti-tank defense

anti_aircraft.note: AA protection provided by attached First Army AA units and RAF air cover

supply_logistics.supply_status: ADEQUATE TO GOOD - Division arrived fresh from UK with full equipment (January 1943). Supply lines from Algiers and Bone ports (200-350km depending on position). Part of First Army buildup for final Tunisia offensive. Q1 saw heavy combat (Sedjenane, Hunt's Gap) with some equipment losses, but resupply maintained. By late Q1, division preparing for final offensive (April-May 1943).
notes: Division arrived 3 January 1943 with full UK equipment scales
Convoy from Liverpool (24 Dec 1942) to Algiers (3 Jan 1943)
500-mile road/rail journey to frontline near Sedjenane
Heavy combat in January-March: Sedjenane battles, Hunt's Gap defense
Equipment casualties replaced from First Army stocks
Q1 operations: defensive battles, counterattacks, preparation for final offensive
Artillery ammunition expenditure high during defensive battles
Strong RAF air support compensated for lack of organic AA

weather_environment.terrain_type: Northern Tunisia - hilly terrain with river valleys (Sedjenane valley), mixed agricultural land and rocky hills. More restrictive than Western Desert. Beja sector features extensive hill positions. Better cover but channelized movement.
notes: Northern Tunisia winter: cold nights, mild days, frequent rain
Sedjenane valley: narrow, hilly, restricted maneuver
Hunt's Gap: defensive hill position, good artillery fields of fire
Mud conditions from winter rains affected mobility
Terrain favored defensive operations (division's primary Q1 role)
More vegetation and cover than Western Desert
Hill fighting required different tactics than desert warfare

subordinate_units.note: Departed Gourock, Scotland 6 January 1943. Defended Hunt's Gap (late January-February) with artillery and Churchill tank support from North Irish Horse. Moved 100 miles south on 2 April to assist attack towards Pichon near Kairouan.

composition: 2/4th Battalion, King's Own Yorkshire Light Infantry
subordinate_units.note: Departed Liverpool 6 January 1943. Led division's attack on 28 March with 128th Brigade in reserve, reinforced by 36th Infantry Brigade, 1st Parachute Brigade and French units.

Held Sedjenane valley positions (January-February). Battle of Sedjenane (26 February onwards): costly counterattacks on 27 February and 2 March with No. 1 Commando and artillery support. Pushed back 15 miles over three weeks to Djebel Abiod after abandoning Sedjenane on 4 March.

tactical_doctrine.role: British First Army infantry division for Tunisia Campaign. Arrived January 1943, immediately committed to defensive operations in difficult northern Tunisia terrain. Held critical sectors at Sedjenane and Hunt's Gap against German offensives (February-March 1943). Participated in final offensive operations (April-May 1943) leading to Axis surrender.
special_capabilities: Fresh division from UK with full modern equipment
Three well-trained Territorial Army brigades (Hampshire, mixed counties, Sherwood Foresters)
Experienced defensive operations in restrictive hill terrain
Effective artillery support (substantial fire at Hunt's Gap)
Combined operations with Churchill tanks, commandos, and French units
Adaptability: shifted 100 miles south on 2 April for new offensive operations
tactical_innovations: Integrated Churchill tank support at Hunt's Gap (North Irish Horse)
Combined operations with commandos (No. 1 Commando at Sedjenane)
Coordination with French units in multi-national operations
Defensive use of hill positions in restrictive terrain
Rapid redeployment capability (100-mile move in April)
known_issues: No desert warfare experience (fresh from UK)
Learning curve for North African terrain and climate
Heavy casualties in Sedjenane battles (139th Brigade pushed back 15 miles)
Difficult terrain limited mobility and maneuver options
First combat experience for many soldiers
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Not a desert division - operated in northern Tunisia's hilly, agricultural terrain. Adaptations: Mediterranean winter climate, hill fighting tactics, defensive operations in valleys, coordination with armor in restrictive terrain. Different challenges than Western Desert divisions.

historical_context.operational_status: Active - Full combat operations throughout Q1 1943
major_battles: Arrival in Algeria: 3 January 1943 (convoy from Liverpool 24 December 1942)
500-mile journey to frontline near Sedjenane (early January)
Battle of Sedjenane (26 February - early March 1943): 139th Brigade counterattacks, withdrawal to Djebel Abiod
Hunt's Gap defense (late January-February 1943): 128th Brigade with artillery and Churchill tanks
Divisional attack 28 March 1943: 138th Brigade lead, multi-national force
Redeployment south 2 April 1943: 128th Brigade to Pichon sector
notes: Division departed UK: Divisional HQ and 139th Brigade 24 December 1942 from Liverpool
128th Brigade departed Gourock, Scotland 6 January 1943
138th Brigade departed Liverpool 6 January 1943
Arrived Algiers 3 January 1943, then 500-mile journey to Sedjenane front
Immediately committed to combat - no acclimatization period
Q1 1943: FULL QUARTER OF COMBAT OPERATIONS (3 January - 31 March)
Part of V Corps, British First Army (Lieutenant-General Kenneth Anderson)
Territorial Army division with strong regional identities (Hampshire, Sherwood Foresters)
Fought defensive battles against German offensives (Operation Ochsenkopf)
139th Brigade under Brigadier Chichester-Constable fought costly Sedjenane battles
128th Brigade successful defense of Hunt's Gap with tank/artillery support
Division participated in victory parade in Tunis 20 May 1943
Continued to Italy: Salerno landings September 1943 under new commander Hawkesworth

scenario_suitability: Battle of Sedjenane (26 Feb - 4 March 1943): 139th Brigade defensive/counterattack
Hunt's Gap defense (late Jan-Feb 1943): 128th Brigade with Churchill tanks
28 March 1943 divisional attack: multi-national combined arms
British First Army vs. German Afrika Korps in hill terrain
Defensive operations in restrictive valley terrain
Fresh UK division vs. veteran German forces
wargaming_data.experience_level: Regular (Green at start of Q1, gaining experience rapidly)
special_rules: Fresh from UK - no desert experience but full equipment
Territorial Army division - regional cohesion within brigades
Learning curve for first month (January): -1 experience modifier
By March: combat veteran status from Sedjenane/Hunt's Gap battles
Strong artillery support (substantial firepower at Hunt's Gap)
Churchill tank support available (North Irish Horse)
historical_engagements: Battle of Sedjenane (26 February - 4 March 1943) - 139th Brigade

source: WebSearch: British 46th Infantry Division Tunisia January March 1943
WebFetch: britishmilitaryhistory.co.uk - Tunisia 1942-1943 British Infantry Divisions
Historical records: Division arrival 3 January 1943, Battle of Sedjenane, Hunt's Gap
Operation Ochsenkopf historical accounts (German offensive February-March 1943)

chief_of_staff.reason: Chief of Staff name for 46th Division not found in available sources for Q1 1943
sources_checked: Standard divisional staff organization used for estimates
chief_of_staff.mitigation: Consult UK National Archives war diaries for divisional staff roster

brigade_commanders.reason: Only 139th Brigade commander (Brigadier R. C. J. Chichester-Constable) documented in Sedjenane battle accounts. 128th and 138th Brigade commanders not found.
brigade_commanders.mitigation: Consult regimental histories (Hampshire Regiment, Lincolnshire Regiment, Sherwood Foresters) for brigade commander information

exact_arrival_dates_by_brigade.reason: Division HQ and 139th Brigade arrived 3 January 1943. 128th and 138th Brigades departed UK 6 January, arrival dates in Algeria not precisely documented (estimated mid-January).
exact_arrival_dates_by_brigade.estimate_method: 6-day convoy voyage (standard UK-Algiers) + 500-mile journey = ~12-17 January arrival for 128th/138th Brigades
exact_arrival_dates_by_brigade.mitigation: First Army war diaries or shipping records would provide precise dates

known_gaps: Brigade commander names except Chichester-Constable (documented above)
Exact casualty figures for Sedjenane and Hunt's Gap battles
Precise vehicle allocations by brigade (estimated from divisional establishment)
Detailed battalion-level TO&E (approximated from standard structure)
Exact dates of 128th/138th Brigade arrivals in Algeria
notes: IMPORTANT CONTEXT: Division arrived 3 January 1943 - FULL Q1 1943 COMBAT QUARTER
Unlike 1st Infantry Division (arrived 9 March), 46th Division fought entire Q1
Heavy combat immediately: Sedjenane, Hunt's Gap defensive battles
139th Brigade pushed back 15 miles at Sedjenane (26 Feb - 4 March)
128th Brigade successfully defended Hunt's Gap with tank/artillery support
Equipment and personnel based on standard 1943 British infantry division with combat attrition
Unit-specific: Commander (Freeman-Attwood), brigades (128th Hampshire, 138th, 139th Sherwood Foresters)
Tier 2 due to: brigade commander gaps (except 139th), reliance on standard establishments, exact casualty/loss data unavailable
Higher confidence than 1st Infantry Division (which had only 22 days in Q1)
Division represents British First Army characteristics: fresh from UK, immediate combat commitment
Territorial Army regional structure (Hampshire, Sherwood Foresters) vs. Regular Army divisions
